title: Will a political party gain an overall majority of seats in the House of Commons at the next UK General Election?
possible_answers: Yes, a political party not listed above
No political party will gain an overall majority
preds:
after thinking about @Joseph-Noko's post  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/932517I I confess to possibly having excessively minimized the following possibilities:
-a big millennial voter turnout might boost Labor or Lib Dems as that demographic leans remain and the Torys are clearly pro-Brexit
-the issue of the NHS may cause swing/undecided voters to go Labor or Lib Dem
-possible polling errors, or the result being on the outer edge of the margin of error in polls, which could be magnified in seat distribution.  I'm a bit un-nerved by the YouGov's poll director's statement that they can't rule out a hung parliament.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/932678

Although Jeremy Corbyn is considered by many to be unfit for the role of prime minister Labour could see support from anti-Brexiteers who might otherwise vote Conservative. Added to this there could be a surge of support for Lib Dem by millennials who are also thought to be generally against Brexit.  Therefore it is highly possible that there will be a hung parliament or even a Labour majority.

Cursory look at polls - to be more accurate, it is necessary to know the polling data in each seat in contention. Most safe seats can be safely ignored. Some other questions to consider: Which age groups were asked their opinions? How much effect will tactical voting have? How was polling carried out by phone, internet, etc?  Remember previous election polling was abysmal for the most part.

A 70/30 split seems prudent. The polling model that accurately predicted the election outcome two years ago suggests that the Conservatives are on course to win 339 seats, Labour 231, the Liberal Democrats 15 and the Scottish National Party 41. Although that would give Mr Johnson a majority of 28, the poll’s range of possible outcomes stretches from 367 Tory seats to only 311. “Based on the model we cannot rule out a hung parliament,” Anthony Wells, YouGov’s director of political research, said. https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/mrp-election-poll-tory-lead-narrows-ahead-of-final-election-rallies-zj57279t6

Updating based on latest YouGov poll and recent tightening. I still think Johnson will pull a majority.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-12-10/key-poll-predicts-majority-of-28-for-johnson-in-u-k-election?utm_source=url_link

Latest from Economist 
“ The leaders of Britain’s two main parties, Boris Johnson of the Conservatives and Jeremy Corbyn of Labour, are spending the day before the general election criss-crossing the country, in a last-ditch attempt to win voters over. The Conservatives are likely to secure the most seats, and probably a majority: they lead Labour in the polls by an average of ten points. But that figure conceals a wide variation among pollsters, who put the Tories’ lead at anything between 15 percentage points (enough for a landslide) and just six (which might mean a hung parliament). The latter would be good news for Labour, because Mr Johnson, having promised a hard Brexit, would find it hard to woo other parties into coalition. Mr Corbyn, on the other hand, might be able to call on the support of the Scottish Nationalists, who will probably be the third-largest party, and perhaps the Liberal Democrats, the fourth.”

Although Conservatives lead in the last YouGove poll shrank I believe this increases the odds of a conservative majority as it mobilizes more Conservative voters (avoids complacency among Torie voters). This view is also visible in GBPUSD which has barely retraced and is still trading towards a 1yr high.

YouGov's MRP poll is out (https://yougov.co.uk/topics/politics/articles-reports/2019/12/11/final-2019-general-election-mrp-model-small-), forecasting a slimmer Conservative majority in the House of Commons, and raising the possibility of a hung parliament, which is now within a margin of error. Consequently, I have revised my forecast downwards, to 70:30. Having looked at all the polls, this time round, there is very little difference between MRP model conclusions and national average conclusions: a Tory majority is the most probable outcome, but a hung Parliament is possible. So what will happen? I go to first principles: what is the defining issue of the election and who wins on that issue, if anyone? The issue is easy to see: Brexit. In another era, "NHS for Sale" would cost the Tories the election, but Brexit is the big hairy beast that makes the slithering snake beside it look like a guardian angel. Furthermore, in terms of shifting votes, the Clinton-Trump election is instructive: for all his mendacity, Hillary Clinton had bigger trust issues than Donald Trump, precisely because people expected him to be duplicitous. "NHS for Sale" as an example of an issue that is not-Brexit, is not something that can really hurt the Tories because it is not a surprise. Who wins on the defining issue: the Tories, because they offer closure, whether you think Brexit is a historical triumph or the greatest self-inflicted geopolitical blunder of the last 6 or so decades. This does not mean a hung Parliament won't happen, I am simply explaining why a Tory majority is more likely. I will deny saying any of this when a hung Parliament emerges!

Currently at work so I can't update my rationale very well. Reading through the polls that use MRP, they predicted somewhere between 340 on a low end to 360. But, the circumstances with brexit were much different especially when it come to her own party.  The bleedover effect is something that is interesting in the circumstances. Looking at electoral prediction maps, there is a real possibility that the ideas of 
Labour are being attacked by the Tories. That makes me think that there are going to be more errors in favor of Tories than with labour. Which gives it a majority.  Back in late October early November, there were pamphlets that were found that showed that the Tories were gearing up for an ugly election this month. The pamphlets were blaming labour for the problem of brexit. That makes me think that Tories are better prepared with a better narrative.   There are also reports of the labour being undersatisfied with their narrative.  That gives me pause to believe that they're doing well. And they're planning on pivoting in the next two days.  That worries me that they're changing message which makes me believe that they're not doing so hot.  Then there's the Hillary problem. I was reading a report about tactical voting.  Where people who support the Tories are not voting for their first choice.  Messaging doesn't work as well with an uninspired leader because of the initial believers. If we use an analogy of a Bass Diffusion Differental Equation. Word of mouth doesn't spread as well because it's not engaging.   This makes me believe that the Tories are going to get somewhere in the 350 seats range.

Maybe this isn't a great way to analyze data, but I thought I'd give it a try to see if it clarified things.   I went to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2019_United_Kingdom_general_election#
and looked at all the polling since the candidate lists were finalized.   I looked at polling by company/poll, assuming that each poll used the same methodology each time.  I looked for trends:  up or down during that period, and between the last 2 polls done by that company. The "mega" (ha!) trend is downward for Conservative support since Nov 15th, with ALL polls showing lower (or the same) results as first reported after 11/15.   However, the most recent trend (looking at the last 2 polls by each pollster) shows an upward trend for Conservatives by 6 out of 11 pollsters. I also looked at seat projections as recorded on wikipedia.  There has been consistent projections of a significant Conservative majority.  The most recent projections are for a greater majority, though less than in mid-November, averaging in the last 4 projections a 33-seat majority for Conservatives.  These projections seem to mirror the opinion polls:  Conservative support was high in mid-Nov and then dropped, but is rebounding. The things that make me nervous about my 90% Conservative forecast are:
-reports that there's a much larger number of undecided voters than in the past
-reports that younger voters may turn out in high numbers and swing the vote to Liberals Absent those things, I'd be at 100% Conservative majority. @Joseph-Noko, @OttoRenner

Grounded on YouGov's MRP polling methodology (https://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/x92rnn48yd/Sky_TheTimes_VI_191126_w.pdf), I go with a Tory majority. BrandsEye experimented with huge success in forecasting Brexit and trump's victory, but, alas, they are not in the game this time round. Datapraxis, who also use an MRP model, predict a 38-seat majority, though, Paul Hilder, the CEO, adds this proviso: “We have never seen as many undecided voters this late in the campaign. As many as 80-90 constituencies are still up for grabs. A much larger Conservative landslide is still possible - but so is a hung parliament.” YouGov MRP model suggested the Tories were on course for a majority of 68.  Best for Britain, a group lobbying for a second referendum, commissioned an MRP poll that forecast 345 seats for the Tories - or a majority of 40. Stopping a Tory majority is still possible. I think undecideds will either stay at home or mirror the rest of the electorate and give the Tories a majority. However, Best for Britain suggests tactical voting by 41,000 voters in just 36 swing seats could prevent prevent a Tory majority. I am disinclined, silly fellow that I am, to believe that people are capable of that degree of cynicism and calculation, but it remains a possibility.  I have discounted other polls because they work on national averages, rather than on a seat-by-seat basis, like the MRP based polls, creating a distortionary effect. However, even national averages show a Tory lead (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2019_United_Kingdom_general_election).  broadly, as @nigster's analysis shows, there is a durable average lead across various polls of over 10%, and the Tories only need a 7 point victory to secure a majority. This is a come-to-Jesus moment: the Tories will secure a majority.  My feeling is, few have an appetite for second referendums, new negotiations with the EU, etc. Sheer Brexit exhaustion allied with a very good ground game on the part of the Tories, who have managed to define the election -as they nearly always do-, Corbyn's indecisive and divisive leadership, and the lack of a true third party, should see the Tories emerge as the biggest party in Parliament, with a majority.  Finally, politics is about simplicity. As @TheFutureIsHere said, "The conservative party promises to follow through on the referendum result about Brexit. This is a clear message that will probably appeal to the majority of voters." I am not sure what Labour really wants. No Brexit? New negotiations? A vote for Labour does not offer clarity and I believe simplicity of messaging and rigorous organization trumps all.  [Cue a very confident reversal of my analysis come YouGov's poll!]

What's more is that the polled vote share for remain (52%) and leave (48%) has been relatively static (3). In drawing on these points, my forecast remains unchanged and in favour of a hung parliament. The UK political culture is the most volatile in my memory, and any prediction is highly provisional at best. That the 'traditional' media (Press and broadcast) is overwhelmingly Right-wing and repeating the "get Brexit done" mantra daily is a big help to the Tories, but the party is itself badly split on Brexit and will lose marginal seats on that basis, plus the leader is seen as a blithering pathological liar. If voters continue to be entranced by the Brexit Spectacle then the Tories will likely be the largest party, but if they consider practical and social issues (eg housing, economy, NHS) above Brexit then Labour may be the biggest party. The push for tactical voting is a joker in the pack, as is the surge in voter registration amongst young people. The likeliest outcome is a hung parliament, then a 'progressive alliance' of Labour, SNP, Plaid Cymru, and Greens. A less likely outcome would be a repeat of the Libdem-Tory coalition if the Tories concede a second referendum on Brexit.

ICM Unlimited (2019) Dec 4, states that: What do the public think will happen? With people’s perceptions of the likely election outcome perhaps playing a part in who they end up voting for, ICM this week sought to understand what the public think will happen come December 12 (Para. 4). Three in ten people think that the most likely outcome of the election is that the Conservatives will win ‘with a majority of less than 50 seats’ (29%), making it the single most commonly predicted outcome. One in five people think that the Tories will win ‘with a majority of more than 50’ (19%), meaning that, overall, just under half of the public think that a Conservative majority is the most likely outcome (48%). Just under a quarter of people think that a hung parliament is the most likely thing to happen come December 12 (23%), while one in ten think that a Labour majority is the most likely eventuality, with 6% predicting a Labour majority of less than 50 seats and 4% predicting a Labour majority of more than 50 seats. One in five people do not know what outcome they think is most likely (19%). Among those who intend to vote Conservative, confidence seems to be high. Combining the four in ten who think that the Conservatives will win with a handsome majority of over 50 (39%) and the four in ten who think they will win with a more modest majority (43%), over eight in ten of those who intend to vote Conservative think that their party of choice will win a majority (82%) (Para. 4-7).

Everybody over the last week seems to be showing Labour up and the LibDems down, and in most cases both models show a decline in the Conservative majority over what was predicted a week ago as a result.  The question is, is this a fluctuation or a trend?  Are we seeing just a random bump, or are we seeing people moving toward their true voting intention? In a normal election, we'd expect a trend; people shifting from the smaller parties to their more-preferred larger one, which will mostly look in the polls like LibDem to Labour.  I was suspicious that it would be atypical this time because of the large role of Brexit and the LibDem position as the lead anti-Brexit party.  But like last election, the issues seem to be steadily moving away from Brexit regardless. I accordingly am updating further in favor of "No political party will gain an overall majority".  Unless something dramatic happens, I expect to see a moderate additional shift from LibDem to Labour, with a smaller, partially-offsetting shift from Brexit to Conservative, and thus an increase in the chance of the Conservatives not managing to get a majority.

Analysis: In the raw popular support, the Conservatives seem to be averaging the same overall support that they had on polling day in 2017; all the polls (except the Independent's) have them within the margin of error on the 43.43% they got that year.  Labour support, however, is way down, with the Liberal Democrats way up.  The Brexit Party seems to be polling ahead of UKIP's 2017 results, though it's small enough that polling errors might be an issue.  It is notable that many polls are only polling Brexit Party in constituencies where it's running, which is substantially fewer constituencies than UKIP was running in in 2017. So, there are perhaps two paths to Labour managing to recover. The first is Johnson making a serious blunder like May did on long-term care and scaring voters currently voting their Brexit preference into swapping to a "Stop the Tories" vote.  The problem with that is that everybody remembers what happened to May, and is presumably going to do his best to avoid that. The second is anti-Brexit voters currently supporting the LibDem/Green/Cymru alliance looking at a Conservative majority and deciding they prefer Labour's wishy-washiness to Johnson being able to push through his deal.  The problem with the second is that a good deal of the anti-Brexit coalition is from a "Brexit is bad for business" perspective, and neither Corbyn's comments on the sort of Brexit he wants nor his new back-to-the-Seventies Labour manifesto do anything but push that sort of voter away from Labour.

A signifcant minority of traditional Tory voters will not back BoJo due the hardline Brexit stance. These voters are unlikely to spill into Labour (due to Corbyn) - Libdems are more likely to get 80-90% of the loss. Therefore the calculation is: how large is the minority? Accounting for the Remain vote among Conservatives at around 40%, this could be the swing from Conservative to Libdem, which increases the probability of hung parliament ("No majority").

https://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/homepage.html "The crucial number is the lead of the Conservatives over Labour (or vice versa if Labour is ahead). That ranges from 0pc (ComRes) to 14pc (Kantar). If this lead is around 6pc, then the Conservatives should get a bare majority in parliament, which is marked by the light blue diagonal line. But if this lead is at least 9pc, then they will get a more comfortable majority, marked by the dark blue line. On the other side, Labour need a lead of about 6pc for a bare majority themselves, shown by the light red line. The current average prediction is shown by the red dot, marked "Average" which is within the bare Conservative majority region. Fascinatingly, only one pollster (Hanbury) thinks the parties are actually in this zone. Five of the other pollsters are predicting another hung parliament, while four indicate a large Conservative majority. This increases the uncertainty about the possible election outcome. It could be another a hung parliament, or it could give a comfortable Conservative majority."

Going to answer this initially with what I think the chances of the four options are to gain a majority, then some other things I am bearing in mind. I will also consider some base rates, and the simplest steps to a majority. If I look like I have built a story/convincing myself of something, please let me know in the comments. A majority is 326 seats. I will email asking for confirmation but it does not seem to me that a Lib Dem led coalition would count - to me, an overall majority means one party winning one. 1/Yes, the Conservative Party - 58% In the Politico Poll of Polls (https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/united-kingdom/) the conservatives currently have a lead of 13%, sat at 37%, ahead of the labour party on 24%. They have a clear main priority, “Get Brexit Done” which to the low information voters in their target seats and to a brexit weary voting population is a simple message.  Most voters do not pay attention to the vast majority of politics, but know big picture things - “we voted to leave, we haven’t left, why - Parliament” This election is “necessary” as there is no majority in Parliament for any resolution to the main issue of the day. I expect there to be a difference in the quality of the 2017 election campaign, which was not necessary, had no focus and ended up with poor policies front and centre. Most campaigns make very little difference unless you run them very poorly. They will be squeezed in London and in some remain voting constituencies, but in those constituencies the vote could well be split between the Labour and Lib Dems. There is a threat this could equally apply to Labour picking up seats where the Brexit Party splits the Conservative vote in seats they haven’t won in decades.  I think if you look at the lead they have, and the message, I think they will get a majority. I am not predicting a landslide, but I think they will get over the line. 2/Yes, the Labour Party - 1% It would have to be a massive reversal of fortunes for this to occur. They have been flat at around 24/6% in the poll of polls since Boris Johnson became leader. Their own leader is very, very unpopular although there may be a “shy labour” voting effect going on, where people dont like the leader but still revert to type on polling day. They do not have a clear message, and I do not think this is likely at all.  3/Yes, a political party not listed above - 0% There has not been a majority non labour or conservative government since before the second world war. No party is expected to do this, but even if it turns out that coalitions count they are likely to be headed by the Labour party not any other. 4/No political party will gain an overall majority - 41% Given the potential for splits in all the areas where the conservatives, labour and lib dem parties this is the second most likely option after a con majority. I do not think that tactical voting will work out for the opposition parties. Other remarks There have been 20 general elections since 1945, 2 have resulted in hung parliaments, 10 wins by a conservative gov and 8 by labour, but this includes 1 minority gov and 1 coalition. I am hesitant to apply this slight advantage to the conservatives in winning for two reasons 1/brexit referendum in 2016 2/this is the 3rd election into a conservative administration. These two reasons mean that the voters may not see this as a direct continuation of a conservative government, with a very different national conversation focused on brexit.  Unlike in the US, fundraising is not regularly released so we cannot use it as a proxy to see how donors view the strength of a campaign.  As this is a winter election, it should be expected that don’t knows/less motivated voters are less likely to want to brave the cold to vote. However, in the UK voters can use postal votes. Turnout has been increasing since the low in 2001/returning to the historical norm of 70ish%, it will be interesting to see if this continues.  https://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/homepage.html  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Kingdom_general_elections https://www.politics.co.uk/comment-analysis/2019/10/31/election-2019-region-by-region-guide-to-the-most-volatile-el https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/united-kingdom/

The UK is currently divided after the Brexit vote with a majority (albeit a slim one) voting in favor of leaving the EU.  Further, the Brexit debacle has been playing out for a long time with the uncertainty weighing on the masses. With Brexit inevitable, it is likely that the people weary of Brexit and the uncertainty that has been hanging over their heads, the gives a clear advantage to the Conservative party as this is the only party likely to get Brexit finished as soon as possible.  Further clinching the election for the conservatives is the deal secured by Boris Johnson which has some support and gaining momentum.

As a first-pass forecast, some major factors to consider: - Conservatives are leading in the polls currently [1]
- Polling can shift. Comparison class - When Theresa May called for an election, the Tories had polling in their favor but the situation reversed so much so by the time voting took place that the Tories ended up losing seats. 
- Voters will see the election as a de facto vote on Brexit. Leave/Remain is reshaping how voters identify themselves in relation to others [3]. Since the Brexit vote was relatively close, the election may be close as well
- LibDems are likely to do well, taking votes away from Labour. Could they take some votes from the Tories? According to one poll, 5% of Tories support a 2nd referendum [2]
- BJ has alienated some conservatives from the party
- BJ is in a relatively strong position after securing a deal for which the Parliament indicated support
